Distress decreased significantly throughout the intervention, but increase a small amount after the intervention ended (remaining lower than its initial level).
In sum, positive effects were demonstrated on most outcome measures, although some of these effects began to diminish after the intervention ended.

Latina immigrants 
are also less likely to have access to and seek appropriate mental health services less often than U.S.-born women and women of other racial/ethnic groups. They face barriers to accessing quality mental 
health care due to lack of health insurance, few culturally and linguistically competent providers, and/or the stigma associated with seeking care for mental health.

column45:
Promotoras were recruited and trained to serve as lay health educators in mental health and coping skills, using a linguistically and culturally tailored curriculum for recently immigrated Latinas.  The training curriculum consisted of at least six 2- to 3-hour training sessions on mental health, stress, and coping skills and how to reach out to women in the promotoras’ social networks. 

After the training, the promotoras met monthly with the curriculum facilitator (licensed clinical social worker) as a group, for four to nine booster sessions, to complete a monthly log of their activities and to discuss their outreach experience. These sessions reinforced promotoras’ skills and provided opportunities for promotoras to share their experiences disseminating information and support to compañeras.

Promotoras identified up to three women (compañeras) in the community with whom to share their mental health promotion resources and information on a regular basis with the goal of preventing and reducing negative mental health outcomes.

column215: ALMA demonstrated the potential impact of a lay health educator model in improving depressive symptoms and stress for Latinas. Interventions such as ALMA that focus on building self-care strategies are crucial to reducing preclinical symptoms and addressing health care disparities that results from unavailable or underused mental health services

column215: The empowering in-service training did not significantly decrease the work stress of foreign nurse aides in LTC facilities in this study. Of the six work stressor domains, the scores for general job tasks decreased after intervention.The training improved nursing knowledge and skills and helped the nurse aides in in their management of emergency situations. However, scores in other domains such as patient care tasks, relationships between coworkers, relationship with supervisors, workload/scheduling,  and  facility design/maintenance did not decrease significantly.

column3: Listening to refugees: How traditional mental health interventions may miss the mark.

column19: Recently resettled refugees from Burundi, Burma, Congo, Rwanda and Bhutan. These refugees were resettled in a large, metropolitan city in the Southwest United States that annually resettles roughly 10 percent of refugees sent to the United States.  On average, 1 in 10 adult refugees resettled in Western countries suffers from post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD), 1 in 20 suffers from major depression, and 1 in 25 suffer from generalized anxiety disorder.
column21: Refugees from Burundi, Burma, Congo, Rwanda and Bhutan resettled in a large, metropolitan city in the Southwest United States (N.B. only 3 (10.7%) were employed)

1. Over 18 years old

column45: The three types of interventions were the community-based psycho-educational group meetings, office-based counseling, and home-based counseling. Office- and home-based counseling were conducted by licensed mental health professionals using a trauma-informed approach
column50: Other: Symptoms of depression and anxiety
column215: Specifically, our typical conceptualization of the client-counselor dyad does not seem as good a fit for resettled refugee clients as compared to a group intervention where there are opportunities for group support and psychoeducation related to their needs.
column216:
1. Group Program Structure (Participants felt that a mental health intervention should have a group focus, rather than an individual focus. They appreciated the camaraderie that developed out of a shared sense of purpose in the mental health support group meetings and felt that this was a missing component in individual meetings with their mental health counselors.)

2. Program Content (Participants had many ideas about the content that should be included in an effective mental health group intervention, many of which centered around adjustment to life in the United States as a newly resettled refugee)

3. Minor Theme: Frequency/Duration of Intervention and location (Participants expressed a desire to attend at least two, and often three or more group meetings each week in order to have their needs met. Many felt that the program duration should extend longer than 8 weeks and should include a long-term follow-up component a number of months after the regular meetings had concluded. They emphasized the importance of holding meetings in an easily accessible location.)
column217:
Group Program Structure 
1. Social Support (participating in the mental health sup-port group with their peers helped to reduce feelings of social isolation)
2. Mutual Aid (the assertion that the group program structure was an effective mechanism to create a sense of shared responsibility and obligation to one’s fellow community members, the mental health group was an opportunity to share ideas and knowledge and also a place to receive and exchange practical help from others)
3. Empowerment (participants sense power through group membership)

Program Content
1. System Navigation (participants expressed the need for assistance in navigating the health and social services landscape in the US, especially skills and knowledge related to accessing health and medical services) 
2. Literacy and Language (participants express the need for English language literacy assistance, and assistance in attaining US Citizenship)
3. Advocacy (the need for advocacy on behalf of the participants, especially related to interactions with employers and medical or social service settings)
4. Counseling (the importance of building the relationship between the individual client and the counselor as an essential component of establishing trust and honesty in a mental health intervention)
5. Ethnic-specific Differences (differences between the interests demonstrated by the interviewees)

column3: Reducing refugee mental health disparities: A community-based intervention to address postmigration stressors with African adults.
column6: Reducing Refugee Mental Health Disparities: A Community-Based Intervention to Address Post-Migration Stressors with African Adults
column12:
To adapt and test the feasibility, acceptability, appropriateness, and preliminary outcomes of the Refugee Well-Being Project (RWP) model with refugees from several countries in Africa, and to test five hypotheses, as by guided by the conceptual model. 

To promote well-being and alleviate psychological distress among Hmong adult refugees.
column13: Prevention of stress/anxiety/depression; Management of stress/anxiety/depression
column14:
Other: Mixed Methods, Within-Group Longitudinal Design
Cohort study
column17: University of New Mexico School of Medicine Research Allocation Committee, University of New Mexico Department of Pediatrics Research Committee, University of New Mexico Signature Program in Child Health Research, St. Joseph Community Health Services, New Mexico Department of Health Office of School & Adolescent Health and Con Alma Foundation
column19:
The study was implemented over three years (2006-2008) in a large city in the Southwestern United States. 

Between 2002 and 2009, 232 African refugees were resettled in New Mexico, and represented a high need, underserved population. Most refugees share similar experiences such as overcoming past traumas and the challenges of adjusting to life in a new place. However, refugees’ experiences also differ widely, based upon their particular cultures, past war exposure and loss, their different social locations (e.g., gender, age, religious affiliation, sexual orientation), and how these social locations have shaped their experiences.
column21: African refugees resettled in New Mexico
column22: All African refugee adults who had been resettled in the past two years
column45:
Refugee participants and undergraduates worked together for at least 6 to 8hours per week for six months on two intervention components. 

1. Learning Circles: 
Learning Circles (LCs) occurred twice weekly, in two hourmeetings between refugee adults and children and undergraduate students. LCs began with cultural exchange, which provided a forum for refugees and undergraduates to learn from each other through discussions aided by interpreters. Cultural exchange was facilitated by one undergraduate and one refugee each evening who worked together to decide upon and develop a topic of interest. Discussion topics included healthcare, safety issues, labor unions and worker rights, roles of men and women in the U.S., treatment of people of African descent in America, and performance arts including music, drumming, and dancing. The second component of the LCs was one-on-one learning, during which undergraduates and participants worked in pairs. Refugees chose areas of learning such as English competency or completing job applications. Each refugee studied with the same student every time, fostering the development of comfort and trust. Undergraduates were also engaged in learning about the culture, experiences, and knowledge of refugee.

2. Advocacy: 
The advocacy component was adapted from the Community Advocacy model. Based on relationships formed in the LCs, each student worked with one or two refugee partners to engage in mutual advocacy. They spent a minimum of two to four hours each week together to mobilize community resources to address unmet needs identified by the refugee partner. Transferring advocacy skills to the refugees was emphasized so that increased access to resources would be sustained after involvement in the program ended. Example areas of advocacy included: accessing healthcare; finding affordable housing; and working with educators and refugee families to support student progress.
column49: 4 time-points at 3-month intervals (Pre-intervention, midpoint, immediately post-intervention, and three months post-intervention)
column215:
Participants experienced significant increases in English proficiency and quality of life and significant decreases in psychological distress.

The growth trajectory models and qualitative data suggest that the intervention had positive impacts on African participants’ mental health and well-being. Thus, the current study provides additional preliminary evidence that addressing psychosocial stressors through the creation of space for mutual learning, development of reciprocal relationships, and valuing of refugees’ strengths, concurrent with the mobilisation of needed resources may be important in improving quality of life and psychological well-being.

The positive findings regarding the feasibility, acceptability, and appropriateness of the intervention suggest that the RWP model can be adapted for ethnically and linguistically diverse refugees who resettle in different parts of the United States.

column3: Findings for a CBT support group for Latina migrant farmworkers in western Colorado.
column6: Findings for a CBT Support Group for Latina Migrant Farmworkers in Western Colorado
column12: The purpose of the present study was to evaluate a culturally-responsive cognitive-behavioral support group for migrant farmworker women of Mexican descent.
column13: Management of stress/anxiety/depression; Stopping re-occurence of stress/anxiety/depression
column21: Migrant Farmworkers in the Montrose Area of Western Colorado
column22:
1. Must be a female migrant farmworker
2. Be of Latino Descent
3. Must be from the Montrose Area in Colorado
4. Must be recruited as part of a project assessing the mental health of 157 migrant farmworkers in the Montrose Area
5. Appear to be at risk for mental health difficulties (according to elevated migrant farmworker stress and depressive symptom scores)

1. Male migrant farmworker

column45:
Intervention: group cognitive-behavioral therapy that was culturally adapted for female migrant farmworkers in Western Colorado 

Participants attended 6-sessions of the intervention within the span of 6 weeks. The support groups were co-led by a female clinical psychologist and a female promotora (women who were current/former migrant farmworkers that are trained as health educators). Each group leader was bilingual and bicultural. 

The psychologist presented educational material on the relevant weekly topic which would open up the conversation/discussion among the support groups. The topics covered include: (1) understanding and coping against stress, anxiety and depression; (2) increasing hopefulness and self-esteem (“developing one’s own style and personality”); (3) empowering group members to better individuate, assert themselves, and succeed in the larger society; (4) family issues related to nurturance and childrearing, discipline, family functioning and communication, and acculturation gaps (i.e., children acculturating at a quicker pace than parents); and (5) understanding and recovering from domestic violence and other traumatic experiences.

Group leaders also used CBT techniques such as imaginal and in vivo exposure; assertiveness training; cognitive strategies such as problem solving, cognitive restructuring, and learning to recognize factors that contribute to stress, anxiety, and depression; and behavioral strategies such as increasing group members’ engagement in pleasurable activities, positive activity scheduling, and the bolstering of coping skills.

To be more culturally appropriate, the intervention was delivered in Spanish and promotoras were used as a group leader. The intervention was delivered in a local church. Participants were involved in the decision-making process and an emphasis was made on culturally-valued interactions. During these sessions, women were encouraged to talk about their difficulties as a farmworker and discuss about different topics.
column50: Stress; Anxiety; Depression; Other: hopelessness, self esteem
column215: According to the criteria set forth by Jacobson and Truax (1991), 83 % of the women achieved clinically significant pretreatment-posttreatment change and end-state functioning for migrant farmworker stress and depressive symptoms. For pretreatment-followup, 100 % of women achieved clinically significant change and end-state functioning for migrant farmworker stress and depressive symptoms; 75 % for self-esteem; and 50 % for anxiety and hopelessness

column3: Evaluation of an organizational health intervention for low-skilled workers and immigrants.
column6: Evaluation of an organizational health intervention for low-skilled workers and immigrants
column12: To study an organizational health intervention for low-skilled workers and immigrants in Germany
column17: German Federal Ministry of Education and Research
column19:
We conducted our study with 74 kitchen assistants in a canteen section of a welfare facility (Company A), 81 workers in the control and assembly departments of a service production company (B), and 266 workers handling the arrival, warehousing and issuing of goods in a car accessory manufacturing plant (C). The sample was comprised of 50.4% immi-grants (42.3% first-generation, 8.1% second-generation) originating mainly from Kazakhstan (9%), Russia (8.6%), Turkey (7.8%), Poland (5%) and Italy (3.6%). 


Materials -  Structured observations of the training sessions were conducted. Here, two independent observers assisted in the training sessions (for the peer mentors and the line managers) and marked on a structured observation sheet whether each content element was implemented according to the procedure. 

Qualitative, semi-structured interviews with trainers and company management as well as the trained peer-mentors and line managers were held. The interviews covered the relevant contexts, implementation processes and the mechanisms of change. The authors assessed the success factors for mentoring and for organizational interventions as perceived quality of the training, role clarity and common knowledge about the goals and contents of the program
column20: 5 mechanisms for change: 1) company management encouragement mechanism; 2) role model mechanism; 3) peer-mentor support mechanism; 4) participative work improvement mechanism; 5) line manager support mechanism
column21: Low-skilled workers (half of whom were immigrants)
column22:
1. Working as a low-skilled worker in Germany 
2. Working in one of the 3 included companies participating in the study
column23:
1. Not a low-skilled worker
2. Not working in Germany 
3. Not working in one of the 3 included companies participating in the study
column45:
1. Peer-mentors were recruited among the low-skilled workers after having been identified as an individual that coworkers often seek help and support from. These peer-mentors attended 3 fortnightly spaced training sessions of four hours each. Here, they were trained on how to provide emotional and instrumental support by engaging in active listening and by initiating collective problem-solving and changes to improve the work situation in a participative way. During normal work hours, they acted as peer-mentors for their coworkers. 

2. Line managers of low-skilled workers (esp. first-level managers) attended 4 fortnightly spaced sessions of four hours each. Here, they were trained to improve emotional and instrumental social support, to hold effective staff meetings for collective problem- solving, and to communicate information. 

For 6 months, the intervention group received social support from peer mentors and line-managers. 

3. A workshop for company's senior and middle managers so that company management would be able to incorporate the core elements of the intervention into its day-to-day management concepts

column215:
- The workers in the intervention groups showed significant decreases in diastolic and systolic blood pressure across a time period of six months
- The intervention and control groups differed in changes in psychosomatic complaints. We found that workers in the control group reported a significant increase in psychosomatic complaints, but workers in the intervention group did not.
column216:
M1: The company managers reported in the interviews that they were encouraged to participate because of the target-group specific interventions at low costs. The company management 
encouragement mechanism (M1) was successfully released by utilizing the services provided by nonprofit agencies such as health insurance funds in Germany.

M2: The role model mechanism (M2) was successfully released by peer-mentoring in all three companies

M3: peer-mentors increasingly supported their coworkers. The results mostly supported Hypothesis M3. The peer-mentor support mechanism (M3) was activated by the intervention in all three companies

M4: Peer-mentors initiated high-quality changes at work in a participative way such as improving the organization of shift work, creating a new rest area, cleaning up workplaces and reducing social conflicts at work in all three companies. The participative work improvement mechanism (M4) was clearly released by the intervention in all three companies

M5: The trained line managers reported in the interviews that they did not feel threatened by the empowered workers because they felt sufficiently involved in the peer-mentoring implementation process. However, they also reported that they were not motivated to participate in an intervention that was designed to enhance their support for improving the work situation and health of their subordinates because they felt too stressed themselves. They wished their own work situation to be improved first. The line manager support mechanism (M5) was not activated by the intervention program in all three companies
column217:
Mechanisms of Change 
1. Company Management Encouragement Mechanism (Company managers were were encouraged to participate because of the target-group specific interventions at low costs.)
2. Role Model Mechanism (Peer mentors were highly motivated to participate and to fulfill their new roles)
3. Peer-Mentor Support Mechanism (peer-mentors increasingly supported their coworkers)
4. Participative Work Improvement Mechanism (Peer-mentors initiated high-quality changes at work in a participative way such as improving the organization of shift work, creating a new rest area, cleaning up work-places and reducing social conflicts at work)
5. Line Manager Support Mechanism (Support given by line managers during the implementation process)

column3: Effect of a spiritual retreat on perceived stress of Nigerian Catholic immigrant sisters in the United States.
column6: Effect of a spiritual retreat on perceived stress of Nigerian Catholic immigrant sisters in the United States
column12: Examined whether participation in 6 day spiritual retreat results in changes in perceived stress and whether that depends on demographic characteristics
column13: Prevention of stress/anxiety/depression; Management of stress/anxiety/depression; Stopping re-occurence of stress/anxiety/depression
column19: Study participants were recruited from 178 members of a Nigerian religious institute residing in various states. These Nigerian Catholic immigrant sisters were sent to different states in Northeast, Midwest, Southeast, and Southwest of the UnitedStates by their central authority to engage in different ministries. Some teach in schools, some care for the sick in their homes and hospitals, and others are engaged in pastoral ministries. Most of the members live in communities, and their length of stay in the United States ranges from one–25 years.All had the same kind of religious training, speak the same local language and speak the English language.
column20: Data collected from open-ended questions were analyzed for themes that may explain the participants' perspectives on their retreat experiences and assist the researchers in describing how the retreat experience may relate to the experience of perceived stress.
column21: Participants were women religious (religious Catholic sisters/nuns) from Nigeria who initially migrated to the United States at various times within the last 30 years.
column22:
1. had the same kind of religious training, 2. speak the same local language and 3. speak
the English languag
column23:
1. Any member of the institute who attended, but left before the end of the spiritual retreat
2. Declined participation
column24: Voluntary; Other: Convenience sampling from church
column45:
Spiritual-based retreat activities were delivered to participants to provide them with renewed energy, inner resources to discern what truly matters in life, enhanced sense of meaning and purpose, and improved self-efficacy. 

Each day started with communal singing of the Divine office, then a 30-minute mindfulness meditation and ending with Mass accompanied by uplifting traditional songs. Meals were eaten in common, allowing participants to listen and share their thoughts and experiences. They had an hour of open dialogue with the retreat moderator (clergy) both in the morning and in the evening. It was focused on the virtues of forgiveness, charity, patience, tolerance, service, abandonment to God’s will, and a call to live a life of love and authenticity as contained in the religious institute’s constitution.

They had a one and half hour rest after lunch followed by an evening community prayer and meditation and ending with the adoration of the Blessed Sacrament. Participants could go to confession (sacrament of reconciliation). Some had individual dialogues with the retreat moderator. 

Although silence was encouraged and observed majority of the time, participants were allowed to talk during meals and had an hour of social gathering every evening to share stories, sing traditional songs and engage in traditional dance. The night ended with a community night prayer and a hymn to the Blessed Virgin Mother.
column49: T1: before retreat, T2: during day 3 of the retreat, T3: immediately after retreat
column215:
The significant overall decline in perceived stress during and immediately after the spiritual retreat may have been due to the opportunity participants had to fully engage in various spiritual exercises. 

The results of the study revealed the importance of taking time off from one’s usual routine activities to participate in a spiritual retreat, which has been found beneficial to mental and physical health.

The findings of the study add to the evidence that spiritual intervention may provide another avenue for effectively coping with stress since it enhances one’s sense of identity and self-efficacy, which weakens one’s perception of stress promoting individual overall well-being.
column216: Themes were identified from the 3 short open-ended questions:(1)“What are the perceived stressors in your life?”, (2)“Reflecting on your involvement in this religious and spiritual activities this week, are there specific activities you con-sider most helpful in dealing with your life stresses?” and (3)“Do you plan to continue to engage in those practices after the retreat?”

column3: Social and Emotional Wellbeing (SEW) intervention for mental health promotion among resettled Bhutanese adults in Massachusetts.
column6: Social and Emotional Wellbeing (SEW) Intervention for Mental Health Promotion Among Resettled Bhutanese Adults in Massachusetts
column12: To assess the Social and Emotional Well-Being (SEW) program's effect on engagement in health-promoting behaviors (coping, social networking, and conflict resolution) and mental health outcomes (anxiety, depression, and stress) among resettled Bhutanese adults in Western Massachusetts
column13: Prevention of stress/anxiety/depression; Management of stress/anxiety/depression; Stopping re-occurence of stress/anxiety/depression
column21: All 44 participants attended and completed all intervention sessions, along with baseline and 7-day post-intervention assessments. The mean (SD) age of the participants was 30.6 (11.5) years. In our study, 88.6% of participants were 44 years or younger (< 25 years: 36.3%, 25–34 years: 31.8%, 35–44 years: 20.4%), 9% aged 45–54 years, and 2.27% aged 65 years or older. Sixty-eight percent of participants were female, 59% were married, 86% were literate, 43% had a job, 80% never smoked, 95% never consumed alcohol, and 18% had any chronic diseases (Table 1). The mean (SD) duration in the United States was 5.6 (2.9) years. The median (range) exercise days per week were 2 (1–7).
column22:
1. Resettled Bhutanese refugees aged 18 years or older 
2. Living in Western Massachusetts 
3. Giving informed consent to participate in a program and surveys voluntarily
column23: Those not physically or emotionally well enough to be interviewed
column24: Phone; Voluntary; Other: In collaboration with churches
column45:
The SEW program has five modules. 

Module 1: Managing Stress includes health education on health hazards of stress, practice exercise in identifying stress management techniques, yoga practices, and breathing exercises. 

Module 2: Strengthening Communication Skill includes education on improving intra- and inter-cultural communication skills and practice exercises in identifying useful communication techniques.

Module 3: Strengthening Social Networking Skill includes education on building up cross-cultural social networking skills and practicing exercises to identify social networking techniques. 

Module 4: Problem Solving includes practice exercises in trying three best relevant tips for man-aging stress and strengthening coping, communication, and social networking skills every week and keep a logbook.

Module 5: Create a Healthy Family Environment includes sharing three lessons and encouraging family members to practice relevant health tips and do exercises together as a family event.

The SEW program is a community-based, culturally tailored health education and problem solving activity (60 min), breathing exercises, and yoga (60 min) in a group setting once weekly for 5 weeks. We implemented our program using a participatory group discussion approach, including once a week face-to-face educational sessions, role play, yoga practices (20 simple low-risk yoga poses), and breathing exercises,  at the training hall of a local church.

The first hour of each session included: a brief health education lesson, a small group discussion identifying culturally tailored problem-solving approaches, and making a plan for a daily practice of at least three problem solving measures that would help reduce stress or build up necessary skills for the remained of the week. In the second hour, participants enjoyed breath-ing exercises and yoga. A team of facilitators, including a bilingual researcher (first author), community leaders (third and fourth authors), a holistic nurse, and a certified yoga trainer, implemented all sessions.

Educational Materials were provided to participants, covering culturally tailored stress management; strengthen-ing coping, communication, and social networking skills; and pictograph and video recordings on breathing exercises and yoga practices. Participants were encouraged to practice problem-solving measures, do breathing exercises and yoga together with their family members, and record their home practices in homework logbooks.
column49: Baseline (pre-intervention), Post-Intervention (7 days after the intervention)
column50: Stress; Anxiety; Depression; Other: Coping Strategies, Social Support, Social Networks, Family Conflict Resolution
column215:
Our participants reported significant improvement in health-promoting behaviors and mental health outcomes across our SEW program among resettled Bhutanese adults in Western Massachusetts. 

Our pre- and post-intervention survey data indicated a more than a 50% reduction in the prevalence of anxiety and depression among Bhutanese adults after the intervention. Moreover, our participants reported improved skills in coping adaptively in a new culture, seeking help and support for mental health problems, and other life skills in conflict resolution across the program’s course that are a well-known target mechanism to improve mental health.

column3: Effects of health education for migrant females with psychosomatic complaints treated by general practitioners. A randomised controlled evaluation study.
column6: Effects of health education for migrant females with psychosomatic complaints treated by general practitioners: A randomised controlled evaluation story
column12: The effectiveness  of use  of migrant health  educators in  the general practitioners’  care for  female migrants with  psychosomatic problems was evaluated to contribute to the improvement of the care for these patients
column13: Management of stress/anxiety/depression; Stopping re-occurence of stress/anxiety/depression
column17: Municipal Health Service Rotterdam Rijnmond, The Netherlands Organisation for Health Research and Development
column19:
Turks  and  Moroccans, people  from  Islamic  cultures,  form  the  largest  immigrant populations  in  The  Netherlands.  

They  visit  their  GPs  more often than autochthonous Dutch patients. The target group of the Bridge Project was Turkish and Moroccan female patients between  18  and  65  years  of  age,  visiting  their  doctor  with muscular   pain  caused   by  tension  and  other  stress-related symptoms  with  a  probable  psychosomatic  cause.  

These  pain problems, e.g. tension headache, back pain, shoulder or neck pain, were rated by their GPs as psychosomatic in origin.
column21: Female Turkish and Moroccan patients were recruited from GPS working in one or two-doctor practices situated in disadvantaged neighbourhoods of Rotterdam. These patients who had visited these GP's practices frequently over   a   3-months   period   complaining   of   pain   caused   by muscular  tension  and  of  other  stress-related  symptoms  as assessed   by   their   GPs.
column22:
1. Female Turkish or Moroccan patient
2. Patients who, despite exhaustive physical examinations did not show abnormalities 
3. Patients who were not happy with their progress despite having receiving treatment 
4. Patients whom the GP's could not think of any further treatment
column23:
1. Evidence of serious pathology (physical or mental)
2. Any patient who resided in Turkey or Morocco for more than 5 months, consecutively
column45:
The intervention strategies follows the characteristics of:  information transfer and counselling appropriate for the patient’s culture and language, facilitation of communication between GP and patient, and transfer of information on relevant culture-specific matters aimed at the GP.

Specific to the Bridge Project, the health educators helped the subjects understand the origins   and   symptoms   of   psychosomatic   complaints   and accompanied  the  patients  to  the  GP  to  ensure  that  doctor and  patient  fully  understood  each  other.  The  peer  educators provided  advice  and  taught  skills  the  patients  could  use  to change their beliefs about their psychosomatic complaints and promoted  their  self-efficacy  to  cope  with  these  complaints.

The intervention protocol comprised the following phases of patient support:   (1)   clarification   of   physical   and   psychological complaints  to the  patient,  (2)  clearly formulating  the  request for  help  and  optimising  communication  between  patient  and GP, (3) providing information to increase the patient’s ability to restore balance in stressors and coping in personal life in eight sessions of group education, and (4) conclusion and evaluation.

A  tailored  counselling programme  was  devised  for  each patient. The education sessions and interventions were conducted by one Moroccan–Arabic health educator, one Moroccan–Berber health educator and two Turkish health educators. All the health educators   had   been   trained   to   deal   with   the   topic   of psychosomatic  disorders,  had  been  given  an  introduction  to mental  health  care  facilities,  and  they  had  been  trained  to demonstrate relaxation exercises and to facilitate role-playing in the group education sessions.
column48: Mean intervention duration per patient was 12 months
column49: T1: Baseline Interview, T2: Post-Test Interview
column50: Other: Perceived Stressful Situations, Knowledge of the relationship between pain and stress, Social Support, Mental Health
column215: Many patients referred by their GP showed a need for the migrant health education intervention. Their perceived general and psychological health and coping abilities improved through the intervention as a whole, despite the constant burden of stress from  which  the  patients  suffered.  Not  all  outcome  measures have been affected due to among others the diversity of physical and psychological complaints the patients suffered from, non-compliance to the intervention protocol, especially to the group education   sessions,   the   patients’   relatively   high   level   of knowledge  on  the  relationship  between  stress  and  pain,  and a perceived decrease of disability caused by the pain over time.

column3: Improving the psychosocial work environment at multi-ethnic workplaces: a multi-component intervention strategy in the cleaning industry.
column6: Improving the Psychosocial Work Environment at Multi-Ethnic Workplaces: A Multi-Component Intervention Strategy in the Cleaning Industry
column8: International Journal of Environmental Research and Public Health
column12: To evaluate the impact of a multi-component intervention on the psychosocial work environment at a multi-ethnic Danish workplace in the cleaning sector.
column19:
Immigrants are often recruited into low status and low paid jobs such as cleaning. In Denmark,  as in other European countries, the proportion of immigrants in the cleaning industry has increased markedly in recent years. In 2000, workers with immigrant background represented approximately 23% of the Danish labour force employed as traditional cleaners. This percentage increased to 35% in 2006, and in larger cities the number is markedly higher

Individual semi-structured interviews, assisted by professional interpreters when necessary, were conducted with the cleaners at their work place three weeks before and three weeks after the intervention. An interview guide was developed which consisted of open-ended questions designed  to solicit information about the cleaners’ background and their perceptions of interaction and collaboration with colleagues before the intervention as well as their expectations in regard to the intervention. After the intervention, the cleaners were asked to evaluate the different intervention components, and to tell about their experiences as well as their overall perception of the outcome of the intervention.
column21:
All the cleaners employed at the school where the intervention was carried out, ten women and four men, participated in the intervention. They originated from six different countries including Romania, Thailand, Turkey, Serbia, Philippines, and Denmark.

Six of the immigrant cleaners had lived and worked in Denmark for less than two years (newcomers) and six had been in Denmark for more than ten years (long-term residents). Two cleaners were native Danes.
column22: All cleaners employed at the school where the intervention carried out
column45:
1. Work-related Danish lessons for cleaners with immigrant background (3 h per week for 6 months): The aim of the course was for the cleaners to be able to read the cleaning plans and talk to colleagues, supervisors, and customers about cleaning equipment, detergents, materials, and cleaning plans. Furthermore the cleaners should be able, in Danish, to call in sick and to talk about everyday life. The lessons included group work.

2. Vocational training courses held by an Adult Vocational Training Centre on working techniques, detergents, surfaces, and safety (8 half days): The courses were carried out in Danish; however, instructions about safety were interpreted into relevant languages. The lessons included group work. 

3. Workshop on job satisfaction and teamwork (2 half days): The purpose of the workshop was to become aware of the benefits of working in a multi-cultural group of employees and to improve well-being and job satisfaction. 

Through exercises, games, and conversation the workshop focused on the importance of: • Attitudes towards work • “The good workday” • Recognition and praise • Increased community among colleagues (e.g., through role plays on the difference in being met with recognition or indifference) The workshop also included activities which were not related to work such as being taught a dance. 

4. Staff meetings with increased frequency: The meetings focused on the implementation of the intervention and on topical topics such as how the collaboration on washing of cleaning cloths could be improved.

5. Social events including a summer party
column46: Migrant workers ; Non-migrants in the same community
column215:
The findings suggest that the psychosocial work environment at multi-ethnic workplaces can be improved by applying multi-component interventions focusing on language proficiency, interethnic communication and collaboration as well as by introducing social events.

According to the interviews with the cleaners, the intervention had led to improved communication, trust, and collaboration. These findings are supported by the questionnaire where social support from supervisor and colleagues, social community, trust, and teamwork seem to have improved together with meaning of work, rewards, and emotional demands. The design of the intervention may provide inspiration for future psychosocial work environment interventions at multi-ethnic work places.
column216:
1. Interaction and Collaboration before the Intervention
2. Expectations among the Cleaners before the intervention 
3. The Cleaners' Perceptions of the Outcome of the Intervention 
4. Supervisor's Perception of the Outcome of the Intervention

column3: Cognitive-behavioral therapy for immigrants presenting with social anxiety disorder: Two case studies
column6: Cognitive-Behavioral Therapy for Immigrants Presenting With Social Anxiety Disorder: Two Case Studies
column12: To present two case studies examining the use of individualized cognitive-behavioral therapy for social anxiety disorder with 2 immigrant clients
column13: Management of stress/anxiety/depression; Stopping re-occurence of stress/anxiety/depression
column17: The National Institute of Mental Health
column19:
1. Mr. M was a 57-year-old married man who contacted a speciality anxiety clinic in a university setting seeking social anxiety treatment. At the time of the intake, he reported that he experienced social anxiety in some situations such as talking in front of a group of people, writing in front of others, speaking with unfamiliar people, and asking others to change their behavior. In addition, he stated that he frequently avoided the aforementioned situations because of his social anxiety. The client reported that writing in front of others at his work caused the most interference in his daily life. 

Mr. M reported that he was born in Central America but that he immigrated to the United States as an adult more than 30 years prior to treatment. He stated that he had experienced problematic social anxiety since his childhood in Central America. As a child, he moved from his hometown, where the majority of people spoke an indigenous language, to a larger city where most people spoke Spanish. He described feeling worried that others might think poorly of him because he did not speak Spanish as well as they did.Mr. M reported that his social anxiety continued through his adulthood and that he used alcohol frequently to cope with his anxiety. He stated that he became sober and used a self-help book to address his social anxiety. However, he indicated that he needed therapy to truly overcome his anxiety

2. Ling was a 32-year-old female who emigrated from China to the United States approximately 3 years prior to the diagnostic evaluation. She had obtained a doctorate in the natural sciences before moving for work. She was single at the time of the diagnostic evaluation but married during treatment.

Ling contacted a specialty anxiety clinic in a university setting due to problems related to self-reported social anxiety and depression. She reported that she had experienced at least some social anxiety since she was a child growing up in China. She described being reserved in school and not having close social contacts. However, she believed that her social anxiety became much more severe when she moved to the United States from China. She indicated that she had not anticipated that a strong interpersonal component would be important for her career, and her distress regarding social anxiety became elevated once this became apparent to her. She also reported that she had been experiencing intermittent feelings of depression since moving from China.
column21: Two  culturally diverse clients who immigrated to the United States, one from Central America and one from China, for whom English was not the primary language
column45:
Cognitive-behavioral Therapy (CBT) for the treatment of Social Anxiety Disorder. The treatment consisted of 16-17 sessions and focused on psychoeducation, cognitive restructuring and exposure  using Hope and colleagues' (2000) Managing Social Anxiety: A Cognitive-Behavioral Approach manual. 

Cognitive restructuring sessions focused on identifying and challenging automatic thoughts. Advanced cognitive restructuring focused on challenging core beliefs. All exposure sessions were conducted as an in-session role-play and were assigned as homework for in vivo exposure
column48: Mr. M (sessions were 50 min weekly, total of 17 sessions), Ling (sessions were conducted twice a week over 16 sessions)
column50: Other: Fear of Negative Evaluation, Social Interaction Anxiety, Social Phobia, Social Anxiety Session Change, Fear and Avoidance Hierarchy
column215: CBT for SAD in two ethnic minority clients were successful of clients with different backgrounds, differing time in the United States, and differing proficiency with English.
column216:
Mr. M's Case: 

1. Follow-Up: (During telephone contact 1 month after the final session, Mr. M reported that he was doing well and continued to attend social events. Approximately 8 months later, the therapist called the client to seek permission to use his case in this article. He informed the therapist that he felt as though he had maintained treatment gains in terms of a reduction in anxiety and avoidance. No formal assessment was done. 

- The clinical severity of Mr. M's social anxiety decreased 4 points 
- Mr M’s final score on the SASCI indicated that he felt as though his social anxiety was much less than when he started treatment, even though his initial scores were very low.
- Mr. M’s scores on general measures of social anxiety decreased over the course of treatment as well. Mr. M’s scores prior to treatment of 38 on the BFNE, 43 on the SIAS, and 26 on the SPS at the start of treatment suggested high levels of social anxiety. At posttreatment, his scores were in the average-to-low range (BFNE = 23, SIAS = 11, and SPS = 3), compared with community normative values (Heimberg et al., 1992; Weeks et al., 2005). These changes are consistent with the improvement seen on the Fear and Avoidance Hierarchy.)

Ling's Case: 
- The clinical severity of her social anxiety decreased 2 points from 6 to 4. This indicates that her symptoms of social anxiety were still clinically severe but had decreased over the course of treatment.
- For the majority of situations, her anxiety and avoidance decreased somewhat. However, it is interesting that her avoidance increased for both initiating small talk and maintaining conversa-tions with coworkers. This is consistent with her report during the termination session that she continued to engage in covert avoidance behavior for these two domains. Also, it is unclear why Ling rated that her anxiety increased at posttreatment for initiating small talk with coworkers, which is inconsistent with her self-report during session and on homework assignments.
- Her BFNE scores decreased from 53 (pre-treatment) to 48 (posttreatment), which is clinically significant and indicative of high levels of social anxiety
- Her scores on the BDI-II decreased dra-matically over the course of treatment. Her score prior to the first treatment session (31) indicates that she was experiencing severe depressive symptoms prior to treatment, whereas her posttreat-ment score (10) indicates that she was experiencing only mild depressive symptoms at the end of treatment.
- At posttreatment, Ling was still experiencing SAD, though there is some evidence of reduction in severity compared with prior to beginning treatment. Also, she no longer met diagnostic criteria for MDD.

column3: Musculoskeletal disorders and stress among home-based lady migrant care workers in Taiwan
column6: Musculoskeletal disorders, psychosocial stress and associated factors among home-based migrant care workers
column12:
1. To investigate the prevalence of musculoskeletal disorders (MSDs) and psychological stress and associations between subjective surveys about MSDs/psychological stress and findings in biomedical examinations

2. To identify the risk factors related to MSDs and psychological stress
column17: (1) Chang Gung Memorial Hospital, Healthy (2) Aging Research Center at Chang Gung University, (3) Ministry of Science and Technology in Taiwan
column19: Female MCWs from developing countries are emerging as important personal care providers and employees at home  settings  in  aging  societies  to  meet  the  societal  needs  caused  by  the  potential  insufficiency  of domestic non-professional HCWs and family members.
column21: 85 home-based female MCWs working for patients at Chang Gung Memorial Hospital, Kaohsiung, Taiwan
column22:
1. Younger than 60 years old
2. Able to speak Chinese or Taiwanese
column23:
1. Not a home-based female migrant care worker 
2. Did not sign the written informed consent form
column24: Voluntary; Other: Convenient sampling at working hospital
column45:
The MCWs either completed caregiver training courses in their home countries or in Taiwan. 

(1) For the caregiver training courses in their home countries, these courses contain at least 90 hours of lectures, clinical practice of nursing and caregiver skills, and emergency management skills. After completing such courses, the MCWs will then be qualified to work as caregivers in Taiwan. 

(2) For caregiver training courses in Taiwan, they consist of 50-60 hours of lectures. These include training on basic nursing, communication and emergency management skills, mental health and stress adaptation, the use of proper body mechanics techniques, use of assistive devices and etc. There are also 40 hours of clinical practice included. After completing such training courses, MCWs become qualified to apply for the national caregiver certification exams.
column48:
1. The caregiver training courses in the MCW's home countries consisted of at least 90 hours of lectures. 

2. For caregiver training courses in Taiwan, they consist of 50-60 hours of lectures and 40 hours of clinical practice.
column56: OR = 5.48, p<0.04) with a MV logistic analysis
column215:
- MCWs experienced some level of psychological stress, with 37.6% of participants experiencing a high level of stress

- Lack of caregiver training in Taiwan was a significant risk factor related to higher psychological stress 

- In  conclusion,  MSDs  and  psychological  stress were  common  among  home-based  female  MCWs. Higher educational levels, frequent transferring and bedside  care  activities,  and  lack  of  domestic  care-giver training (in Taiwan) were the most dominant risk factors of MSDs and psychological stress

column3: A mixed methods evaluation of an intervention to prevent perinatal depression among Latina immigrants
column6: A mixed methods evaluation of an intervention to prevent perinatal depression among Latina immigrants
column8: Journal of Reproductive and Infant Psychology
column12: To evaluate the effectiveness of the Mothers and Babies Course (MBC) to prevent perinatal depression in low-income Latina immigrant pregnant women and mothers receiving Women Infants and Children (WIC) services.
column17: The Maternal and Child Health Bureau, Health Resources and Services Administration, Department of Health and Human Services
column19: Following the last data collection visit, a stratified sample of participants was randomly selected to engage in qualitative exit interviews.
column21: Latina immigrant women with depressive features in Washington DC who sought food and nutrition support
column22:
1.18 years old or above
2. Pregnant or up to 1-year postpartum
3. Spanish-speaking
4. High risk for depression (defined as scoring between 9 and 14 on the PHQ-9)
column23:
1. Did not consent to participate 
2. Withdrew from the study or did not complete the three required interviews
3. Those diagnosed with major depressive disorder (MDD) during the T1 interview

column45: The six sessions included three modules teaching women about the relationship between mood and: (a) thoughts, (b) activities, and (c) relationships with others, consistent with a cognitive-behavioural and attachment theory and adapted to the contextual factors of low-income Latinas. The intervention was taught in Spanish by one or two post-bachelor’s trained bilingual and bicultural research staff and a mental health professional at the FQHC, who received weekly supervision from the first author.
column49: T1: baseline, pre-intervention; T2: post-intervention, 6 weeks after T1; T3: 3 months after T2
column215:
The quantitative results revealed a decrease in the mean depressive symptom scores for women in all 3 groups: completers (4-6 classes), non-completers (between 1-3 classes), and women who attended no class. 
Despite high levels of risk for postpartum depression (PD) as an eligibility criteria for enrolling in the study, none of the participants met the diagnostic criteria for a major depressive disorder at the end of the study period.
column216: 1) Increase emotional awareness; 2) Learn to apply cognitive behavioral concepts; 3) Value the group experience: social comparison and social support; 4) improved intervention outcome
column217:
1. Awareness of mood changes (learnt skill)
2a. Behavioural activation
2b. Cognitive re-structuring
